nameEntry.part: Hillcrest Midwifery Hospital and Toddlers Home
Salvation Army Maternity Home, North Fremantle
Hillcrest Maternity Hospital and Hostel for Unmarried Mothers

biogHist.abstract: Hillcrest Maternity Home in North Fremantle was opened by the Salvation Army in 1922. It continued the previous maternity home, which had been known as the 'Open Door' and 'Hopetoun'. Young women who were wards of the state were admitted, and also private maternity patients. Many babies were adopted from Hillcrest. In 1974, maternity services ceased and the Home was used for aged care.
biogHist.p: Hillcrest was a maternity home in North Fremantle that was run by the Salvation Army. The hospital first opened in 1903 as 'The Open Door' maternity home at premises leased from Mr William A. Saw in Swan Street, North Fremantle. Newspaper articles at the time show that the name was chosen because the Salvation Army wanted to open the door to 'unmarried mothers' who might be shunned by society.

In 1910 the hospital moved to Harvest Road, on a site previously occupied by the Salvation Army's 'Prison Gate' service. The property next door, 'Hill Crest', was donated to the Maternity Home by Mrs Francis Pearse in late 1920 or early 1921. When the maternity services moved into Hillcrest, the previous property was used, for a time, as a Children's Home until 1924, when it became an aged-care facility.
Hillcrest moved to the corner of Kings Park Road and Ventnor Avenue, West Perth, during World War II and returned to the Harvest Road site afterwards.
In a history of Hillcrest written in 1995, information from hospital records relating to 1952-1957 gave insight into the general services offered to the community, and to single mothers:

'2,113 Mothers have been nursed in the Hospital and 367 unmarried Mothers have been cared for in their time of distress, and helped to return to normal rightful living. Hillcrest Senior Citizens' Residence History, 1995'

Hillcrest functioned as a general maternity hospital serving the southern suburbs, but its principal purpose was the admission of 'deserted wives, unmarried mothers, regardless of age, creed or colour'.
A fundraising pamphlet from the 1960s described Hillcrest's hostel for 'unmarried mothers', showing the high rate of adoptions:

'During the last year the Unmarried Mothers section admitted 170 women and girls, 134 babies were born at the hospital and 93 adoptions were carried through. Serving the community in Western Australia, published 1966-1969'

The year referred to is unknown, but would have been between 1966 and 1969. The document reported that 462 babies in total were born at Hillcrest in that year; so more than one third of all births at that period were from single mothers, with around 70 percent of those babies adopted. At the time, this was seen as a positive outcome.
By 1974, maternity services at Hillcrest had ceased.
Hillcrest re-opened in 1978 as an aged-care residence and continued in that role until 2008 when the facility closed.

chronItem.event: Event - Hillcrest Maternity Home was officially opened on 5 April 1922
Address - Hillcrest Maternity Home was located at 23 Harvest Road, North Fremantle

resourceRelation.relationEntry: SA Hospital North Fremantle

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hillcrest photos file
archref.abstract: 'SA Hospital North Fremantle' is a digital copy of an undated photograph held in the Hillcrest photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It shows the Salvation Army's maternity hospital, Hillcrest.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Hillcrest, North Fremantle, 1921

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hillcrest photos file
archref.abstract: 'Hillcrest, North Fremantle, 1921' is a digital copy of a photocopied page from the book, Property Souvenir, Australia; a record of progress, 1909-1921 (p.42). The excerpt is held in the Hillcrest photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The caption reads in part, 'Mrs. F.C. Pearse transferred "Hillcrest" in fulfilment of the desires of her late husband' and dates the image as 1921. Another version of the image is held in the same file and comes from The War Cry dated (by hand) 14 May 1921, with the caption: 'Hillcrest as viewed from Helen Street. The Coachman's House and Motor Garage are seen on the right'.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Hillcrest Hospital 1958, old and new wings

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hillcrest photos file
archref.unittitle: Hillcrest Hospital 1958, old and new wings
archref.abstract: 'Hillcrest Hospital 1958, old and new wings' is a digital copy of a photograph held in the Hillcrest photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The caption reads, 'Hillcrest Hosp. 1958'. It shows the new wing of the hospital, which had been built in 1957, to the right of the original building.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Hillcrest in North Fremantle

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hillcrest photos file
archref.abstract: 'Hillcrest in North Fremantle' is a digital copy of an undated photograph held in the Hillcrest photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, showing its position high on the hill.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Hillcrest exterior view, side (II)

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hillcrest photos file
archref.abstract: 'Hillcrest exterior view, side (II)' is a digital copy of an undated photograph held in the Hillcrest photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It shows the covered verandahs at the side and rear of the main building.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Hillcrest exterior view, side (I)

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hillcrest photos file
archref.abstract: 'Hillcrest exterior view, side (I)' is a digital copy of an undated, mounted photocopy held in the Hillcrest photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It shows the covered verandahs at the side and rear of the main building.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Hillcrest exterior view, front

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Hillcrest photos file
archref.abstract: 'Hillcrest exterior view, front' is a digital copy of an undated photograph held in the Hillcrest photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It shows the original 'Hill Crest' building frontage.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Cornelie Home, Lincoln Street

archref.abstract: 'Cornelie Home, Lincoln Street' is a digital copy of an entry in Southern Soup-Soap-Salvation, a compendium of Salvation Army Social Services in the Australian Southern Territory (p.43). It has some historical information about Cornelie.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Hopetoun Maternity Hospital, Harvest Road, North Fremantle [later, 'Hillcrest']

archref.unittitle: Hopetoun Maternity Hospital, Harvest Road, North Fremantle [later, 'Hillcrest']
archref.abstract: 'Hopetoun Maternity Hospital, Harvest Road, North Fremantle' is a digital copy of an entry in Southern Soup-Soap-Salvation, a compendium of Salvation Army Social Services in the Australian Southern Territory (p.74). It has some historical information about the Hopetoun Maternity Hospital, which became known as Hillcrest.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Matron and sisters at the Salvation Army Hillcrest maternity home, North Fremantle, with some new arrivals

archref.unittitle: Matron and sisters at the Salvation Army Hillcrest maternity home, North Fremantle, with some new arrivals
archref.abstract: This photograph is from an article in the Western Mail which is held on the National Library's website, 'Trove'. It shows some of the newborn babies at Hillcrest, the Salvation Army's maternity hospital in North Fremantle. Many of the babies born to 'unmarried mothers' at Hillcrest were adopted.
